tn.ref: Meshullam was the leader of Ginnethon
tn.text: Ginnethon may be another form of the name Ginnethoi.

The Hebrew text mistakenly leaves out the name of the leader of the family of Miniamin. Some modern versions leave the expression incomplete, as the ULB does. Other versions provide a short explanation to make up for the omission of the leader's name (see UDB).
Maadiah may be another form of the name Moadiah.
names of men (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Another possible meaning is "until the reign of Darius"

tn.ref: recorded in The Book of the Annals
tn.text: This may refer to The Book of Chronicles. The scribes wrote the words in the verses above in a book that recorded the events of each day.

tn.ref: up to the days of Johanan son of Eliashib
tn.text: The records in the temple recorded only up until Johanan.

tn.ref: who stood opposite them to give praise and to give thanks, responding section by section
tn.text: This refers to how they sang some of their songs in worship. A leader or one group would sing a phrase, then one or two groups that "stood opposite them" would sing a phrase in response.

tn.ref: obedience to the command of David
tn.text: King David had commanded the Levites how they were to organize and lead worship.

tn.ref: in the days of Joiakim ... Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor and of Ezra ... scribe
tn.text: The date was fixed by listing those who were leading the Jews at the time. "when Joiakim ... Jozadak was high priest, and when Nehemiah was governor and Ezra ... was the scribe"

tn.ref: Hashabiah, Sherebiah ... Jeshua ... Kadmiel ... David ... Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, and Akkub ... Joiakim ... Jeshua ... Jozadak ... Nehemiah ... Ezra

tn.ref: So the joy of Jerusalem could be heard far away
tn.text: "Jerusalem" is a metonym for "the sound that the people of Jerusalem made." This can be translated in active form. AT: "people far away from Jerusalem could hear the sound that the people of Jerusalem made as they celebrated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: men were appointed to be in charge
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. It is not clear who appointed the men. AT: "they appointed men to be in charge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
things the people gave to the priests

tn.ref: For Judah rejoiced over the priests and the Levites
tn.text: It seems that the people appointed the men because the people of Judah were grateful for the priests and Levites who were serving.

The Levites and priests were not just standing, they were serving in their roles. The meaning can be made explicit. AT: "who were standing before them serving God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

people assigned to each gate, responsible to control access to the city or temple, as well as to open and close the gates at times and for reasons set by the administrator. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:neh:07:01|7:1]].
This sentence tells why the people did what they did in [[:en:bible:notes:neh:12:44|12:45]] and gives us more information about the time when David told people how to worship at the temple.
Zerubbabel was a descendant of King David and one of the governors in the region of Judah.
